results.notes: 4 species of Cantharelles. C. appalachiensis, and 3 others all found within about 1/4 mi. Not visible are the distinctions between the two yellow chanterelles. The thin stiped variety is richer yellow overall and grows in association with Eastern White Pine. The heavier one is slightly less orange, which is noticeable in the field and grows in close association with Yellow Birch. The orange one is single and is in the very same place as one last year.

results.notes:
Growing on the undersides of 2 fallen Pinus bungeana cones under a planted P. bungeana tree. Cephalotaxus harringtonia also present nearby. Hymenium white and finely grandinioid. All structures inamyloid. Monomitic with clamped generative hyphae. Cystidia absent. Basidia urniform and 6-7 spored. Basidia measurements: (13.4) 13.8 – 15.4 (16.4) √ó (4.5) 4.52 – 5.5 (6.4) ¬µm, Q = (2.4) 2.7 – 3.4 (3.7); N = 6, Me = 14.8 √ó 5 ¬µm; Qe = 3. Spores smooth, hyaline, thin-walled and suballantoid. Spore measurements: (3.6) 3.9 – 4.6 (4.8) √ó (1.9) 2 – 2.4 (2.5) ¬µm, Q = (1.7) 1.8 – 2.1 (2.3); N = 30, Me = 4.2 √ó 2.2 ¬µm; Qe = 1.9.

results.notes:
Growing on the underside of a decorticated Pinus stick on the ground. Near Pinus spp., Taxus sp. and Rhododendron sp. All structures inamyloid. Monomitic with clamped generative hyphae. Gloeocstidia yellow and cylindrical to flexuose, with some bifurcate. Gloeocystidia measurements: (20.1) 26.1 – 47.8 (52.6) √ó (4.3) 4.5 – 6.9 (9.7) ¬µm, Q = (3.4) 4.4 – 8.2 (9); N = 30, Me = 36 √ó 5.7 ¬µm; Qe = 6.4. Basidia urniform and 6-sterigmate to 7-sterigmate. Basidia measurements: 15.9 – 16.2 √ó 4.6 – 5 ¬µm, Q = 3.2 – 3.5; N = 2, Me = 16.1 √ó 4.8 ¬µm; Qe = 3.4. Spores smooth, hyaline and thin-walled. Spore measurements: (3.1) 3.2 – 4.1 (4.3) √ó (2.3) 2.34 – 2.8 (2.9) ¬µm, Q = (1.2) 1.3 – 1.6; N = 30, Me = 3.6 √ó 2.5 ¬µm; Qe = 1.4.

results.notes:
Growing on a well-rotted decorticated Quercus alba log. All structures inamyloid. Monomitic with simple-septate generative hyphae. Cystidia scattered. Cystidia hyaline, thin-walled and capitate. Basidia terminal, clavate and mostly 4-sterigmate with occasional 2-sterigmate basidia; arranged in candelabra-like clusters. Basida measurements: (10.8) 11.3 – 18.4 (20) √ó (4.3) 4.4 – 5.3 (5.5) ¬µm, Q = (2.1) 2.4 – 3.7 (4); N = 12, Me = 14.9 √ó 4.8 ¬µm; Qe = 3.1. Spores smooth, hyaline and thin-walled. Spore measurements: (3.8) 4.1 – 5.1 (5.7) √ó (2.2) 2.6 – 3.4 (3.8) ¬µm, Q = (1.3) 1.4 – 1.79 (1.8); N = 18, Me = 4.6 √ó 3 ¬µm; Qe = 1.6.

results.notes: Mixed woods (pine, oak and palm) but found nearest to oaks. Latex was unchanging but stained all parts brown. The scent was offensive but not pungent – smelling almost like chlorine and radishes which gave me the suspicion it would be spicy. I was surprised when the taste was mild and had a lingering umami flavor. Tested KOH and ammonia on the specimen (notes on picture with the circles). In the field I assumed it was a washed out Lactifluus volemus var Flavus but I feel after some reading Lactifluus luteolus is a better fit.

results.notes:
On forest floor/litter under pine, spruce and fir in an old-growth Eastern hemlock stand.
Sequence 100% similar to two GenBank sequences identified as Russula cf. montana from the Great Smoky Mountains (MT237486) and ?Canada (KX579797) and one voucher identified as R. montana from Quebec (MN992513). However, the ITS region is only 93.41% similar to the sequence from the TYPE of R. montana (MT549853) so it is likely that what is referred to as R. montana is a species complex. It is also >99.8% similar to two collections identified as R. bicolor.

results.notes:
A magnificent fruiting along several feet of a log. Fruiting bodies up to 2.5cm long. Appeared distinctly greenish yellow in situ, but plain yellow after being pulled out of the shadows of the log. Gooey, sticky, adhering to anything that touches them, specimens drying to a shriveled, translucent puddle. Only beech, maple, cucumber magnolia immediatly surrounding the log, but the presence of the Callistosporium, and the good macroscopic match to the description of G. luteodiscus from Tsuga, suggests the log might have been a conifer.
Microscopy on this collection by Django Grootmyers:
“All structures inamyloid. Monomitic with simple-septate generative hyphae. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Basidia measurements: (22) 26 – 38.2 (40) √ó (4.6) 4.7 – 6 (6.1) ¬µm, Q = (3.7) 4.8 – 6.8 (8.5); N = 30, Me = 31 √ó 5.4 ¬µm; Qe = 5.8. Spores smooth, hyaline, thin-walled to slightly thick-walled and apiculate. Spore measurements: (5.6) 6.5 – 7.9 (9.1) √ó (3.1) 3.3 – 4 (4.2) ¬µm, Q = (1.5) 1.7 – 2.2 (2.8); N = 30, Me = 7.1 √ó 3.7 ¬µm; Qe = 2.”

results.notes: Collected this foul-smelling Amanita emerging beneath a large Pin Oak growing on a lawn adjacent to a parking lot. The most peculiar feature is the smell…unpleasant, similar to old moldy books or perhaps old musty laundry. The same smell as a previously unidentified Amanita I posted in 2020 (Observation 433979) that was collected in the same location although this specimen does not seem to possess any warts on the cap. A pair of old, desiccated examples were also collected (see photo). Would appreciate help with more specific identification of this interesting mushroom.

results.notes:
On forest floor/litter amongst mosses in an old-growth Eastern hemlock stand.
The highest percent similarity of the ITS region sequence was 97.1% to sequences from vouchers identified as Hypholoma capnoides. I don’t feel that 97% meets the threshold for calling this the collection same species, so my preference would be to call this Hypholoma aff. capnoides to indicate it is similar to but likely not the same taxon.
Microscopic examination is consistent with Hypholoma flavifolium as described by A.H. Smith (1951) Mycologia 43 pp. 515-516.

results.notes:
This is the 1st of 4 observations, of what I believe are all the same species. All found relatively within about 50 yards, and not seen elsewhere on long hike. I am tentatively calling them B. bicolor. Could also be Butyriboletus spp, but none seem like an exact match, especially because it didn‚Äôt really bruise blue. This was a very meaty mushroom. Reticulate over top portion of stipe. No odor, taste very mild and agreeable. At first did not bruise at all, but later bruised blue very slowly. Extremely shallow tube layer. Growing near pine, hemlock, with some beech and maple mixed in.
Standing against the B. bicolor ID is the fact that there is virtually no red on the stipe, and I did not see oaks in the area.
results.location_name: Warren Co., New York, USA

results.notes:
Growing in 2 clusters in a small depression in the cemetery lawn. In bare soil among moss and grass. Between 2 Acer saccharum with Cornus sp. and Quercus sect. Lobatae further away. 3 fruiting bodies caespitose. Pileus glabrous. Veils absent. Gills broadly adnate to short-decurrent. Stems producing a clear liquid when cut. Staining reaction absent. Odor not distinctive. Spore print white. Basidiocarps drying to a horny consistency. Lactifers present in the pileipellis, lamellar trama and stipe trama. Clamps present in all tissues. Pileipellis lacking encrusting pigment. Pileocystidia scattered; smooth and hyaline; cylindrical to ovoid to utriform. Pileocystidia measurements: (21.3) 22.2 – 25.6 (36.5) √ó (7.8) 8.3 – 9.9 (11.1) ¬µm, Q = (2.2) 2.3 – 2.8 (4.7); N = 8, Me = 25.2 √ó 9.2 ¬µm; Qe = 2.8. Caulocystidia abundant; smooth and hyaline; with very variable morphoology: ovoid, clavate, fusiform utriform or lageniform. Caulocystidia measurements: (14.4) 17.3 – 41.2 (46.9) √ó (5.9) 7.4 – 10.5 (13.3) ¬µm, Q = (1.9) 2.2 – 4 (5.2); N = 21, Me = 27.6 √ó 8.9 ¬µm; Qe = 3.1. Lamellar trama lacking a reaction in Melzer’s reagent. Pleurocystidia absent or rare. Cheilocystidia hyaline and smooth; morphology variable: broadly clavate to fusiform to utriform to lageniform. Some cheilocystidia with branched apices. Cheilocystidia measurements: (22.5) 22.6 – 49.3 (66.9) √ó (7) 7.7 – 12.9 (20.2) ¬µm, Q = (1.9) 2.2 – 5.3 (8.9); N = 25, Me = 33.5 √ó 10.4 ¬µm; Qe = 3.4. Basidia clavate and 4-sterigmate. Basidia measurements: (30.6) 30.8 – 35.7 (39.7) √ó (5.7) 6 – 7.5 (9.5) ¬µm, Q = (3.3) 4.2 – 5.4 (6); N = 24, Me = 33.1 √ó 7 ¬µm; Qe = 4.8. Spores amyloid, smooth, and hyaline. Spore measurements: (5.7) 6.1 – 7.3 (7.6) √ó (3.7) 4 – 4.5 (4.8) ¬µm, Q = (1.4) 1.43 – 1.7 (1.8); N = 30, Me = 6.7 √ó 4.2 ¬µm; Qe = 1.6.

results.notes:
I was calling it R. vesca, but the consistently tiny spores (mature, from print) made me scratch my head.

Central Finland.
Picea forest, few Sorbus and Betula scattered around.

Ia; mild; FeSO4 reddish quick; guayac fast strong;

The macro is not looking like R. heterophylla, which seems to be rare in Finland anyways. Maybe the pileipellis without inflated basal hyphae is also pointing more to R. vesca, but these spores… too small no? Also, what about those pointy-tapering pileocystidia with proper intracellular content? can’t find them referenced either…

Has anyone out there looked at the northern Heterophyllae under the scope?
Any other opinions welcome.

results.notes:
Very large specimen, volva remnants are decayed and tinged orange/yellow but are not extruded like normal young muscaria. Stem ranges from cream-white at the top down to orange and yellow towards the bottom. Large egg-shaped club at the bottom of stipe with fuzzy mold-like projections. Cap is flat or nearly flat, serrated cream-white gills that are thin and closely spaced. The texture of the gills are definitely waxy. Top of cap is literred with slightly oranged and browned warts, but when the warts are broken open, they are pearly white. Cap is mostly light orange yellow with almost no variation, except the center of cap is darker, but not quite a different color. Edge of cap has light striations, with no noticable margin. The stipe, when snapped, snaps unevenly and breaks similar to a wet branch, with a nearly hollow center filled with spongy and soft tissue. The smell is reminiscent of portobellos and oyster mushrooms when broken open, but is faint and can only be smelled when the stipe is broken. The tissue of the cap is gradient, from pearly white to the orange found on the top, and the skin of the cap is tough to break and could be peeled.
Edit- the spore print was white, creamy white when left for longer than 12 hours.

results.notes:
Collected by an unknown West Virginia Mushroom Club foray participant. Cap hygrophanous and glabrous; initially dull purple and drying to purplish-white. Stem glabrous and dull purple. Odor not distinctive. All structures inamyloid. Pileipellis a cutis. Clamps present in the pileipellis, lamellar trama, and at the bases of basidia. Lamellar cystidia absent. Basidia clavate and 4-sterigmate. Spores smooth, hyaline and thin-walled. Spore measurements: (4.3) 4.9 – 6.7 (7) √ó (2.9) 3.1 – 3.9 (4.7) ¬µm, Q = (1.4) 1.43 – 1.8 (2); N = 30, Me = 5.7 √ó 3.5 ¬µm; Qe = 1.6.

—

Mirrored on iNaturalist as observation 133259716 on September 1, 2022.
